Unfortunately today we are far from the ideal, so it really pays off to be sensitive to the limits of accountability when you hold people to account and when you are held to account!
Ideally accountability would guarantee that decision makers act responsibly, and at the same time wouldn‚Äôt make them any less effective.

Some tradeoffs are better than others, but in general defending your choices while being responsible is harder than just being responsible or just defending your choices. And also in general accountability gives people assurance that decision makers can be trusted.

This can can make the responsible seem irresponsible and visa versa, it can let decision makers jump through hoops to defend bad decisions, and it can make responsibility much harder to sustain. It depends on how responsibility and accountability works in their particular setting

Responsible decision making is often complex enough that it‚Äôs hard to explain, but people will scrutinize and demand that decision makers can defend their choices, so we have to bridge the gap and keep decision makers accountable using imperfect indications of performance

The big governance/law/politics questions about decisions/conflict/power in cryptocurrency and blockchain protocols are 
1) impossible for anyone today to answer authoritatively or analytically 
2) driving the price of cryptocurrency and 
3) determine the social value of the tech

The value that people derive from using the technology cannot be separated from the governance/legal/political realities of the technology. And it's incredibly harmful and wrong to summarize the value of the tech as coming from "escaping governance/law/politics"
And the adoption of these governance/legal/political doctrines is integral to the social order associated with the technology
In practice, cryptocurrency/blockchain technology is always associated with formal governance/legal/political doctrines, usually under the guise of "basic education"

@johndhaskell @CatalinaGoanta @Erikcason @CryptoLawRev @tabali_tigi @BullyEsq @asglidden @AnjaBlaj @NeerajKA @valkenburgh @cryptoecongames @lex_node @AndoniOlta @Fatalmeh @silkelrifai @awrigh01 @HoffProf @anujdasgupta @stephendpalley @NelsonMRosario @propelforward So I‚Äôd say that law (in its entirety) is very complex, far too complex to be governed by any single legal person, single set of rules. @johndhaskell @CatalinaGoanta @Erikcason @CryptoLawRev @tabali_tigi @BullyEsq @asglidden @AnjaBlaj @NeerajKA @valkenburgh @cryptoecongames @lex_node @AndoniOlta @Fatalmeh @silkelrifai @awrigh01 @HoffProf @anujdasgupta @stephendpalley @NelsonMRosario @propelforward Even when there are legal codes and legal wisdom and legal professions and legal systems that are built up over many many generations, law responds to the new varied disputes that people actually have and are having today

@johndhaskell @CatalinaGoanta @Erikcason @CryptoLawRev @tabali_tigi @BullyEsq @asglidden @AnjaBlaj @NeerajKA @valkenburgh @cryptoecongames @lex_node @AndoniOlta @Fatalmeh @silkelrifai @awrigh01 @HoffProf @anujdasgupta @stephendpalley @NelsonMRosario @propelforward So it is constantly being made and remade, propagated by the people who are involved in conflict, whether are parties to disputes, or as intermediaries or third parties

@johndhaskell @CatalinaGoanta @Erikcason @CryptoLawRev @tabali_tigi @BullyEsq @asglidden @AnjaBlaj @NeerajKA @valkenburgh @cryptoecongames @lex_node @AndoniOlta @Fatalmeh @silkelrifai @awrigh01 @HoffProf @anujdasgupta @stephendpalley @NelsonMRosario @propelforward Because people can have a lot of disputes in a lot of increasingly complicated ways, people often choose to accept things rather than dispute them, social norms are very flexible, and so law is quite scalable and it plays itself out in real time as we have conflict/disputes IRL

@johndhaskell @CatalinaGoanta @Erikcason @CryptoLawRev @tabali_tigi @BullyEsq @asglidden @AnjaBlaj @NeerajKA @valkenburgh @cryptoecongames @lex_node @AndoniOlta @Fatalmeh @silkelrifai @awrigh01 @HoffProf @anujdasgupta @stephendpalley @NelsonMRosario @propelforward What happens is basically that people exercise agency in managing their disputes, people change, reality changes, and so the law is constantly changing, it can be more-or-less established due to repeated similar disputes, it expands into new conflict areas...
